byline.contributor: Barbara Surk reported from Ljubljana, and Sewell Chan from London.
byline.original: By BARBARA SURK and SEWELL CHAN

abstract: Large majority of Slovenians vote in referendum to repeal March 2015 law allowing gay couples to marry and adopt children; vote is setback for Europe's gay rights movement and solidifies division on issue between continent's Western nations and formerly communist central and Eastern countries.
lead_paragraph: Slovenians rejected a law that had made their country the first former communist nation of Europe to embrace legal equality for gay men and lesbians.

headline.main: Slovenians Deliver Major Setback to Same-Sex Marriage in Referendum
headline.print_headline: Slovenians Overwhelmingly Vote to Repeal Law Allowing Same-Sex Marriage

snippet: Slovenians rejected a law that had made their country the first former communist nation of Europe to embrace legal equality for gay men and lesbians.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject
